Introduction

Neural tube defects (NTDs), sometimes called spinal dysraphisms, are congenital malformations arising from incomplete closure of the neural tube during embryonic development.  They are among the most common birth defects, with varying degrees of severity and clinical implications.  The most prevalent forms of NTDs include anencephaly, myelomeningocele, and spina bifida occulta.

Pathogenesis



The CNS develops via neurulation during the third and fourth week gestation (

figure 1
).  During the first stage of neurulation (primary neurulation), the neural plate forms from the ectoderm.  The lateral edges of the plate, known as neural folds, migrate toward the midline and fuse.  Fusion begins in the cervical region and extends rostrally and caudally, forming the neural tube, which is the precursor to the brain and spinal cord.  The open ends of the neural tubes, or neuropores, close at the end of the fourth week.  Following primary neurulation, secondary neurulation occurs, during which the caudal spinal cord forms from mesenchymal cells that integrate with the existing neural tube.



Failure of the neural tube to undergo complete closure and formation can occur at any level from the rostral (cranial) to the caudal end.  Open NTDs, which are the most common type, result from defective primary neurulation, leaving neuronal tissue exposed to amniotic fluid.  In contrast, closed NTDs are covered by overlying skin and are thought to result from impaired secondary neurulation.  The site and timing of the defect determine the type of NTD:



  • Failed rostral neuropore closure causes anencephaly (complete failure) or encephalocele (partial failure).  Anencephaly is characterized by the absence of major portions of the skull and forebrain (
    figure 2
    ), whereas encephalocele is characterized by herniation of the brain and meninges through the skull, typically in the occipital region.
  • Failed caudal neuropore closure causes meningocele, myelomeningocele (eg, spina bifida), or myeloschisis (
    figure 3
    ), all of which involve defects where the spinal cord and/or meninges herniate or remain exposed.
  • Failure of secondary neurulation causes a closed NTD (eg, spina bifida occulta), in which the defect is covered by skin, usually due to the incomplete fusion of the vertebral arch at L5 through S1.


Some of the most common and clinically relevant defects are discussed in this article.

Risk factors



Folic acid is involved in the regulation of neural tube closure; therefore, inadequate maternal folate intake (folate deficiency) is the major risk factor for NTDs.  Folate deficiency may result from inadequate dietary intake, impaired intestinal absorption (eg, inflammatory bowel disease, gastric bypass surgery), or use of folic acid antagonist medications (eg, methotrexate, valproic acid, carbamazepine).



Other risk factors include pregestational diabetes mellitus, maternal fever in the first trimester, maternal obesity, and genetic factors (eg, family history).  NTDs may occur in isolation or as a feature of a genetic syndrome (eg, aneuploidies) or amniotic band syndrome.

Open neural tube defects

Anencephaly



Anencephaly is an open NTD characterized by the absence of major portions of the skull and forebrain (

image 1
).  The fetal brain is exposed to amniotic fluid early in development, resulting in degeneration of the developing forebrain.  Because of the severe amount of missing brain tissue, anencephaly is incompatible with life.  Many fetuses with anencephaly die in utero; those born with anencephaly may retain spontaneous breathing and brainstem reflexes (eg, suck, Moro) but die soon after birth.



Anencephaly is diagnosed by fetal ultrasonography, which typically shows absence of the brain and skull superior to the orbits and elevated amniotic fluid volume (polyhydramnios due to impaired fetal swallowing).  Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein is markedly elevated due to direct leakage from the open neural tube into the amniotic fluid.

Encephalocele



Encephalocele is an open NTD in which intracranial contents (eg, brain, meninges) herniate through a skull defect, commonly in the occipital region.  Large encephaloceles are usually identified on prenatal ultrasonography as a sac protruding from a skull defect.  These are obvious at birth, but smaller encephaloceles may not present until later in childhood.  Neuroimaging with MRI of the brain is often performed after birth and prior to possible surgical management of the defect.  Infants have variable neurologic dysfunction depending on the size and contents (eg, meninges, brain tissue) of the mass.

Myelomeningocele



Myelomeningocele (spina bifida), the most common type of NTD, involves the incomplete formation of the vertebral column, meninges, and skin (eg, vertebral arch defect), resulting in herniation of the spinal cord and meninges (eg, neural tissue bulging into the amniotic cavity) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).  Prenatally, it can lead to the following:



  • Limited fetal mobility within the uterine cavity because it is a space-occupying lesion that may prevent the fetus from assuming a cephalic presentation.
  • Hydrocephalus, which is typically caused by obstructed cerebrospinal fluid flow from a Chiari malformation type II (due to downward displacement of the hindbrain) commonly associated with myelomeningocele.  Ventricular size increases throughout gestation in fetuses with unrepaired NTD and can prevent fetal head descent into the pelvis.
  • Fetal growth restriction.  The exact mechanism is unclear, but overall poor maternal nutrition (eg, folate deficiency) may contribute to growth restriction.


Prenatal ultrasonography may show a complex cystic mass along the lower spine.  At birth, the defect is visible as a protruding red, fleshy mass.  Immediately after birth, the defect should be wrapped in a moist, sterile dressing and covered with plastic wrap to prevent infection and heat loss.  Patients undergo urgent surgical repair, which can result in hydrocephalus requiring a ventriculoperitoneal shunt in over half of infants.  Fetal surgery prior to birth may be offered in select cases.



Despite surgical repair, motor, sensory, and autonomic functions below the level of the spinal lesion are typically affected.  Lumbar or sacral lesions are the most common, often causing complete lower extremity paralysis with loss of ambulation and absence of sensation.  Neurogenic bladder, presenting with urinary retention/incontinence, recurrent urinary tract infections, and potential renal dysfunction, is almost universal.  Treatment with clean intermittent catheterization relieves pressure on the upper urinary tract and helps prevent urinary stasis.  Neurogenic bowel is also common, and a scheduled bowel regimen of laxatives, suppositories, and enemas is recommended to treat constipation.

Closed neural tube defects



Closed NTDs occur when the posterior vertebral arches fail to fuse during embryologic development but the overlying skin remains intact (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  The severity and age of presentation of a closed NTD can vary greatly; many patients are asymptomatic or have only cutaneous findings, such as a lumbosacral hemangioma, lipoma, pit, nevus, or hair tuft (
figure 4
).  However, in some cases, the spinal cord may abnormally attach to surrounding tissues (eg, spinal lipomas, tight filum terminale) and undergo stretching and traction.  This can result in tethered cord syndrome, which can present with (
figure 5
):



  • Back pain, sometimes radiating down the legs, exacerbated by activities that further stretch the cord (eg, bending forward).
  • Lower extremity lower motor neuron signs (eg, hyporeflexia, weakness) due to spinal dysfunction below T12-L1, often leading to gait abnormalities and muscle atrophy.
  • Bladder and/or bowel dysfunction due to impaired spinal cord signaling (neurogenic bladder), with symptoms including urinary incontinence, recurrent urinary infections, and chronic constipation
  • Orthopedic complications (eg, foot deformities, scoliosis), typically related to chronic underlying weakness.


Spinal ultrasonography, which is sometimes performed in newborns with suspicious cutaneous lesions (eg, dimples, hemangiomas), may reveal a thickened filum terminale and low-lying conus medullaris, which are suggestive of an occult tethered cord.  Definitive diagnosis is with MRI of the spine, which can detect spinal cord tethering and any associated spinal cord lesions (eg, lipoma).  Urodynamic studies may also be performed to assess bladder function in these patients.  Surgical detethering is the treatment of choice in a symptomatic patient with evidence of tethering on MRI.

Prenatal screening and diagnosis



Screening for NTDs occurs at 15-20 weeks gestation with ultrasonography and measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP), a glycoprotein produced by the fetus.



  • MSAFP:  Levels are reported in multiples of the median (MoM) using unaffected pregnancies at the same gestational age as reference (
    figure 6
    ).  An abnormally elevated MSAFP level (â‰¥2.5 MoM) suggests an NTD because AFP leaks more readily through a defect to become concentrated in the amniotic fluid and, subsequently, maternal circulation.  However, an elevated level may also occur due to benign causes such as multiple gestation (ie, 2 fetuses each producing AFP) and incorrect gestational age dating (the most common cause).  Therefore, an abnormal MSAFP level requires fetal ultrasonography, which can detect multiple gestations, determine an accurate gestational age, and visualize fetal CNS structures.
  • Ultrasonography:  Routine anatomy ultrasonography is recommended for all pregnancies in the second trimester, and most NTDs can be diagnosed prior to delivery by sonographic visualization of the defect.


If an NTD is detected, amniocentesis may be used as an ancillary test to help characterize the defect and to facilitate further genetic testing (eg, chromosomal microarray) (

figure 7
).  Amniotic fluid consists primarily of fetal urine and does not usually contain acetylcholinesterase (AChE), an enzyme normally concentrated in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).  Therefore, elevated AChE on amniocentesis suggests a leak of fetal CSF into the amniotic cavity from an open NTD.  If ultrasonographic findings are not clear, fetal MRI may be considered.

Delivery



The optimal mode of delivery for patients with cephalic-presenting fetuses with NTDs has not been established, but these patients frequently undergo cesarean delivery due to concerns about trauma to exposed neural tissue during vaginal delivery.  In addition, patients who have undergone prenatal in utero repair (often via hysterotomy) require cesarean delivery due to the risk for uterine rupture with labor.

Prevention



Because neural tube closure occurs at 5-6 weeks gestation (when most patients are unaware of their pregnancy), all patients should begin folic acid supplementation at least 1 month before conception to ensure adequate folate levels.  Average-risk patients require 0.4 mg daily; high-risk patients (eg, prior affected pregnancy, antiepileptic use) require 4 mg daily.

Summary



NTDs (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
) result from incomplete closure of the neural tube during early gestation, which leads to various anomalies of the brain or spine, including anencephaly, encephalocele, myelomeningocele, and spina bifida occulta.  A major risk factor is inadequate maternal folate intake.  Most open NTDs can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography.  The site and size of the defect determine clinical presentation, which ranges from asymptomatic to severely disabling or fatal.  Despite available surgical interventions, many NTDs lead to lifelong disability, making prevention with folic acid supplementation a priority to reduce the incidence of these conditions.
